oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Old Jailer's House: site visit report
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gavin, Michael
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Site visit report on Old Jailor's House. Report notes the justification for the visit and proposed adaptive reuse of the building. The document provides historical information and describes the current condition.

In 1806, Dickson County erected a log jail. On May 30, 1830, a tornado destroyed the jail. In its place, a new jail was constructed using materials from the former courthouse. Finished in 1831, the Old Jailer's House originally served as the county jailor's residence. The two-story, gable-roofed brick building witnessed several periods of construction. In 1920, a single-story, one-room brick addition was added to the side. The Colonial Revival porch and cornice details were also added at that time. Around 1940, a single-story, concrete-block jail facility was annexed to the rear of the building. As part of Charlotte's Courthouse Square Historic District, the building (Lot #39, Public Square) is owned by the Dickson County Historical Society. At the time of fieldwork, the society hoped to "utilize the building as a local history museum, to house its archives and collections, and to host special events and exhibitions."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Historic buildings; Houses and homes; Jails
